children.text: The waterproofing has been installed up to and around the temporary tap stops, which may lead to future water leaks.
The NCC’s Building Code of Australia (BCA) states in section 3.8.1.2 Wet Areas that
‘Waterproof tap and spout penetrations where they occur in surfaces required to be waterproof or water resistant’.

When these temporary tap stops are removed to install the permanent tap fixtures, the hole in the waterproofing that may never be adequately sealed. Plumbers sometimes use silicone to seal the hole, however there is no way to confirm that the material or installation complies with the requirements of the relevant Australian Standard AS 3740 Waterproofing of Domestic Wet Areas, and silicone requires replacement after a few years, which is why we recommend it be properly waterproofed prior to tiling.
